means: 给予选举权( enfranchise的过去式和过去分词 )

sentence.Network_en: If the city's foreign residents are enfranchised, they won't be able to vote until 1996.
sentence.Network_cn: 如果该市的外国居民获得选举权，他们要到1996年才能投票。

sentence.Network_en: In Britain women were enfranchised in 1918.
sentence.Network_cn: 1918年英国妇女获得议会选举权.

PerfectNetExp.abs: it is you enfranchised men . it is the Bernard Shaws and all the rest of them . ( cheers and laughter . ) They say the science of government is only suited to the male sex .就怪那些有公民权的人，就该怪萧伯纳之流，(叫好，笑声)他们声称政治管理只适合男性。

it is you enfranchised men . it is the Bernard Shaws and all the rest of them . ( cheers and laughter . ) They say the science of government is only suited to the male sex .就怪那些有公民权的人，就该怪萧伯纳之流，(叫好，笑声)他们声称政治管理只适合男性。

it seemed to me that he found it difficult fully to understand why , in a country where workers were enfranchised , there was still no workers'government .他似乎觉得很难理解,像英国那样工人有参政权的国家,为什么仍没有一个工人的政府。我的答案恐怕并没有使他满意。
Slaves were enfranchised in the mid - 19 th century ., 十九世纪中期奴隶们都恢复了自由.

energy per pulse [laser game] 每一脉冲能量〔激光游戏〕enfranchised commercial broadcast television station 特许商办电视台English Heritage 英国文物委员会

entry.def: To enfranchise someone means to give them the right to vote in elections.

example.ex: The company voted to enfranchise its 120 women members...
example.tran: 公司投票决定给予其120名女职员选举权。

example.ex: If the city's foreign residents are enfranchised, they won't be able to vote until 1996.
example.tran: 如果该市的外国居民获得选举权，他们要到1996年才能投票。

means.word_mean: 1. endowed with the rights of citizenship especially the right to vote
